Rostóv stopped the horse of a batman or groom of some important personage.
Rostóv began to question the batman or groom.
The batman announced that the Tsar had been driven in a carriage at full speed about an hour before along that very road.
The batman announced that the Tsar was dangerously wounded.
Rostóv said, "It can't be!"
Rostóv said, "It must have been someone else."
The batman replied, "I saw the Tsar myself."
The batman said, "I ought to know the Tsar by now, after the times I have seen him in Petersburg."
The batman said, "I saw the Tsar just as I see Rostóv."
The batman said, "There the Tsar sat in the carriage as pale as anything."
The batman said, "How they made the four black horses fly!"
The batman said, "Gracious me, they did rattle past!"
The batman said, "It's time I knew the Imperial horses and Ilyá Iványch."
The batman said, "I don't think Ilyá drives anyone except the Tsar."
Rostóv let go of the horse and was about to ride on.
A wounded officer passing by addressed Rostóv: "Who is it you want?"
The wounded officer asked, "The commander in chief?"
The wounded officer said, "The commander in chief was killed by a cannon ball—struck in the breast before our regiment."
Another officer corrected the wounded officer: "Not killed—wounded!"
Rostóv asked, "Who? Kutúzov?"
The officer replied, "Not Kutúzov, but what's his name—well, never mind... there are not many left alive."
The officer said, "Go that way, to that village, all the commanders are there."
The officer pointed to the village of Hosjeradek and walked on.
Rostóv rode on at a footpace not knowing why or to whom he was now going.
The Tsar was wounded, and the battle was lost.
Rostóv rode in the direction pointed out to him, in which he saw turrets and a church.
A soldier shouted to Rostóv: "Take this road, your honor, that way you will be killed at once!"
The soldier said, "They'd kill you there!"
Another soldier said, "Where is he to go? That way is nearer."
Rostóv considered, and then went in the direction where they said he would be killed.
Rostóv thought, "If the Tsar is wounded, am I to try to save myself?"
Rostóv rode on to the region where the greatest number of men had perished in fleeing from Pratzen.
The French had not yet occupied that region.
The Russians—the uninjured and slightly wounded—had left that region long ago.
All about the field lay from ten to fifteen dead and wounded to each couple of acres.
The wounded crept together in twos and threes.
Rostóv could hear the wounded men's distressing screams and groans, sometimes feigned.
Rostóv put his horse to a trot to avoid seeing all these suffering men.
Rostóv felt afraid—not for his life, but for the courage he needed and which he knew would not stand the sight of these unfortunates.
The French ceased firing at this field strewn with dead and wounded where there was no one left to fire at.
The French, on seeing an adjutant riding over the field, trained a gun on Rostóv and fired several shots.
The sensation of those terrible whistling sounds and of the corpses around Rostóv merged in Rostóv's mind into a single feeling of terror and pity for Rostóv.
Rostóv remembered his mother's last letter.
Rostóv thought, "What would Rostóv's mother feel if she saw Rostóv here now on this field with the cannon aimed at him?"
